articles.headline: U.S. Allies Jostle to Win Exemptions From Trump Tariffs
articles.snippet: Countries mixed appeals to friendship with threats of retaliation. But the lobbying frenzy risked undermining the ground rules of world trade.
articles.abstract: Countries mixed appeals to friendship with threats of retaliation. But the lobbying frenzy risked undermining the ground rules of world trade.
articles.lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — South Korea made an impassioned appeal to the American secretary of defense and national security adviser, reminding them of its role trying to defang North Korea. Europe pointed out that it was, in fact, a longstanding military ally of the United States.

articles.headline: One State’s Quest to Introduce Long-Term Care Benefits
articles.snippet: A bipartisan effort to tax Washington workers and offer a year of nursing home or other coverage is mired in questions over caregiver qualifications.
articles.abstract: A bipartisan effort to tax Washington workers and offer a year of nursing home or other coverage is mired in questions over caregiver qualifications.
articles.lead_paragraph: OLYMPIA, Wash. — For a few weeks this year, the rarest of things seemed like it was about to occur. A state, in this case Washington, was working to pass a bill that would institute a new payroll tax to help cover the cost of a much-needed service: long-term care in a nursing home, in a personal residence or elsewhere in the local community.

articles.headline: Florida Governor Signs Gun Limits Into Law, Breaking With the N.R.A.
articles.snippet: The $400 million bill imposes new restrictions on firearm purchases and the possession of “bump stocks,” and funds school police officers and mental health services.
articles.abstract: The $400 million bill imposes new restrictions on firearm purchases and the possession of “bump stocks,” and funds school police officers and mental health services.
articles.lead_paragraph: MIAMI — Florida’s nickname has long been the “Gunshine State” because of its plethora of firearms and loose gun restrictions. Then a troubled teenager stormed into a South Florida high school and shot 17 people dead.

articles.headline: Google Is Trying Too Hard (or Not Hard Enough) to Diversify
articles.snippet: The internet giant is being sued by former employees who say the company is going too far with diversity. Other lawsuits accuse it of the opposite.
articles.abstract: The internet giant is being sued by former employees who say the company is going too far with diversity. Other lawsuits accuse it of the opposite.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — In 2014, Google became one of the first technology companies to release a race and gender breakdown of its work force. It revealed — to no one’s surprise — that its staff was largely white or Asian and decidedly male.

articles.headline: Planning Begins for Kim Jong-un Meeting Some Trump Aides Believe Will Never Happen
articles.snippet: The administration is already deliberating over the logistics and location of the meeting, which has still not been officially confirmed by North Korea.
articles.abstract: The administration is already deliberating over the logistics and location of the meeting, which has still not been officially confirmed by North Korea.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A day after President Trump accepted an invitation to meet Kim Jong-un of North Korea, the White House began planning on Friday a high-level diplomatic encounter so risky and seemingly far-fetched that some of Mr. Trump’s aides believe it will never happen.

articles.headline: Trade War Prospect Shakes Part of Trump Base: Midwest Farmers
articles.snippet: Rural voters voice concern that retaliation against tariffs could take aim at American agriculture, which posts a trade surplus.
articles.abstract: Rural voters voice concern that retaliation against tariffs could take aim at American agriculture, which posts a trade surplus.
articles.lead_paragraph: MAPLE PARK, Ill. — Snow and sleet were falling on Eldon Gould’s 500 acres this week, but he was already looking ahead to planting season; depending on ground conditions and the temperature, that could be just several weeks away.
articles.byline: By Monica Davey and Patricia Cohen

articles.headline: ‘ISIS Is Coming!’ How a French Company Pushed the Limits in War-Torn Syria
articles.snippet: The global cement giant Lafarge is facing accusations that it paid ISIS and other militant groups and put its employees at risk to preserve business in war-torn Syria.
articles.abstract: The global cement giant Lafarge is facing accusations that it paid ISIS and other militant groups and put its employees at risk to preserve business in war-torn Syria.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — Mostafa Haji Mohamad, a medical worker, was just starting the morning shift at a cement factory in Syria when gunfire rattled across the desert. The air was stifling, and he and the other employees were on edge.
articles.byline: By Liz Alderman, Elian Peltier and Hwaida Saad

articles.headline: In Britain’s Playgrounds, ‘Bringing in Risk’ to Build Resilience
articles.snippet: After decades spent ratcheting up safety measures, many British educators say the pendulum has swung too far. Bring on the scissors, bricks and mud pits.
articles.abstract: After decades spent ratcheting up safety measures, many British educators say the pendulum has swung too far. Bring on the scissors, bricks and mud pits.
articles.lead_paragraph: SHOEBURYNESS, England — Educators in Britain, after decades spent in a collective effort to minimize risk, are now, cautiously, getting into the business of providing it.

articles.headline: Trump Rollbacks Target Offshore Rules ‘Written With Human Blood’
articles.snippet: Drillers seek to gain from an easing of Obama-era safety and environmental regulations that were adopted after the Deepwater Horizon disaster killed 11 people.
articles.abstract: Drillers seek to gain from an easing of Obama-era safety and environmental regulations that were adopted after the Deepwater Horizon disaster killed 11 people.
articles.lead_paragraph: PORT FOURCHON, La. — A dozen miles off the coast, on a rusty, aging platform, workers in hard hats and overalls spend their days extracting oil and gas from the ocean floor before retreating at night into tiny weather-beaten steel cubes that act as dorms.

articles.headline: With Snap ‘Yes’ in Oval Office, Trump Gambles on North Korea
articles.snippet: How President Trump threw aside caution and agreed to meet with North Korea’s Kim Jong-un in a daring and risky diplomatic gambit to end a nuclear standoff.
articles.abstract: How President Trump threw aside caution and agreed to meet with North Korea’s Kim Jong-un in a daring and risky diplomatic gambit to end a nuclear standoff.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Summoned to the Oval Office on the spur of the moment, the South Korean envoy found himself face to face with President Trump one afternoon last week at what he thought might be a hinge moment in history.
articles.byline: By Peter Baker and Choe Sang-Hun

articles.headline: Dropbox Chief to Join Elite Ranks of Idea-to-I.P.O. Founders
articles.snippet: Drew Houston, chief executive of Dropbox, is set to become a member of a small club of entrepreneurs who steered a start-up through to the public markets.
articles.abstract: Drew Houston, chief executive of Dropbox, is set to become a member of a small club of entrepreneurs who steered a start-up through to the public markets.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — When Drew Houston played computer games like Starcraft in high school, he made some changes so the games ran more smoothly on his friends’ computers.

articles.headline: Out of Public View, Trumps and Kushners Are Talking Business
articles.snippet: The Trump and Kushner families are stepping up their real estate collaborations, blurring the line between family, business and politics.
articles.abstract: The Trump and Kushner families are stepping up their real estate collaborations, blurring the line between family, business and politics.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONG BRANCH, N.J. — Jared Kushner’s family company recently began construction on an oceanfront development in this Jersey Shore city, a project that has the strong backing of local officials, who agreed to support it with $20 million in bonds.
articles.byline: By Ben Protess, Steve Eder and Jesse Drucker

articles.headline: G.O.P. Rushed to Pass Tax Overhaul. Now It May Need to Be Altered.
articles.snippet: The $1.5 trillion tax cut spawned a host of errors and ambiguities in the law that businesses big and small are just now discovering and scrambling to address.
articles.abstract: The $1.5 trillion tax cut spawned a host of errors and ambiguities in the law that businesses big and small are just now discovering and scrambling to address.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The legislative blitz that rocketed the $1.5 trillion tax cut through Congress in less than two months created a host of errors and ambiguities in the law that businesses big and small are just now discovering and scrambling to address.
articles.byline: By Jim Tankersley and Alan Rappeport

articles.headline: My Union or My President? Dueling Loyalties Mark Pennsylvania Race
articles.snippet: Working-class voters are the prize in a widely watched special congressional race on Tuesday, as unions try to line up their pro-Trump members behind a moderate Democrat, Conor Lamb.
articles.abstract: Working-class voters are the prize in a widely watched special congressional race on Tuesday, as unions try to line up their pro-Trump members behind a moderate Democrat, Conor Lamb.
articles.lead_paragraph: PITTSBURGH — The special election deep in Trump country in southwest Pennsylvania on Tuesday has become an acid test for the allegiance of working-class voters, and organized labor has gone all in for the Democrat in the race, Conor Lamb.

articles.headline: A Heartland Company Leads the Media Race
articles.snippet: After buying Time Inc. for $2.8 billion, Meredith is the largest magazine company in the United States, but it’s not about to change its unassuming style.
articles.abstract: After buying Time Inc. for $2.8 billion, Meredith is the largest magazine company in the United States, but it’s not about to change its unassuming style.
articles.lead_paragraph: DES MOINES — Steve Lacy greeted me in his office as if we were old friends.

articles.headline: Lotto Tickets Are Nice, Boss, but Can I Have My Bonus?
articles.snippet: Gamelike methods can effectively motivate workers, in the right circumstances. But as United Airlines recently showed, they can also be alienating.
articles.abstract: Gamelike methods can effectively motivate workers, in the right circumstances. But as United Airlines recently showed, they can also be alienating.
articles.lead_paragraph: It seemed like an epic blunder: United Airlines announced that it was replacing a standard bonus with a lottery that would give nothing to most of its roughly 90,000 workers while awarding lavish prizes, like $100,000 in cash and Mercedes-Benz sedans, to a few lucky winners.

articles.headline: How Trump’s Disdain for the Iran Deal Makes a North Korea Pact Even Harder
articles.snippet: As President Trump prepares to negotiate with the North, it will be watching closely as he decides whether to abandon the landmark 2015 Iran accord.
articles.abstract: As President Trump prepares to negotiate with the North, it will be watching closely as he decides whether to abandon the landmark 2015 Iran accord.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Iranian and North Korean nuclear programs, drastically different but often spoken of in the same breath, are now being thrust together, as President Trump’s determination to kill the landmark 2015 accord limiting Tehran’s capabilities is colliding with his scramble to reach a far more complex deal with Pyongyang.

articles.headline: Saudis Said to Use Coercion and Abuse to Seize Billions
articles.snippet: As the Saudi crown prince comes to the U.S. to court investment, new details cast doubts on his claims of a transparent, legal anti-corruption effort.
articles.abstract: As the Saudi crown prince comes to the U.S. to court investment, new details cast doubts on his claims of a transparent, legal anti-corruption effort.
articles.lead_paragraph: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia — Businessmen once considered giants of the Saudi economy now wear ankle bracelets that track their movements. Princes who led military forces and appeared in glossy magazines are monitored by guards they do not command. Families who flew on private jets cannot gain access to their bank accounts. Even wives and children have been forbidden to travel.
articles.byline: By Ben Hubbard, David D. Kirkpatrick, Kate Kelly and Mark Mazzetti

articles.headline: In Erie, One City Block Is a Trek of Disrespect
articles.snippet: A decaying bridge has ignited a debate over how a struggling city treats some of its poorer residents.
articles.abstract: A decaying bridge has ignited a debate over how a struggling city treats some of its poorer residents.
articles.lead_paragraph: ERIE, Pa. — Despite the “Road Closed” barriers blocking cars and trucks, Elizabeth Feliciano trudged the other morning on foot across the McBride Viaduct, late for school. Arching over a gritty scrap-metal yard and railway line, the graffiti-scrawled 1,170-foot-long bridge links two of this city’s poorest neighborhoods.

articles.headline: The Next Goldman Chief Could Be a Banker Who Moonlights as a D.J.
articles.snippet: The company said Harvey Schwartz would retire, clearing the way for David Solomon, his fellow president and co-chief operating officer, to take the top job.
articles.abstract: The company said Harvey Schwartz would retire, clearing the way for David Solomon, his fellow president and co-chief operating officer, to take the top job.
articles.lead_paragraph: As bake-offs go it was pretty unusual: a part-time disc jockey and a karate black belt vying to be the next leader of arguably the world’s most influential bank.
